text: Math 317 Quiz 1 Practice Solutions 1. Fix a, b > 0. Consider the ellipse on the xy-plane described by the equation (x a )2 + (y b )2 = 1. (a) Set up an integral for the length of the ellipse (you are not required to evaluate the integral). (b) Find the unit tangent vector of the ellipse at the point ( a √ 2 , b √2 ) on the ellipse. (c) Find the curvature of the ellipse at the point ( a √2, b √2). (d) Find the radius of the osculating circle of the ellipse at the point ( a √2, b √2). Solution. (a) We obtain a parametrization ⃗r(t) = ⟨a cos t, b sin t⟩, 0 ≤ t ≤ 2π by setting x a = cos t and y b = sin t. Since ⃗r ′(t) = ⟨−a sin t, b cos t⟩, the length is given by ∫ 2π 0 |⃗r ′(t)|dt = ∫ 2π 0 √ a2 sin 2 t + b2 cos2 tdt. (b) The unit tangent vector is given by ˆT (t) = ⃗r ′(t) |⃗r ′(t)| = ⟨−a sin t, b cos t⟩ √a2 sin 2 t + b2 cos2 t. Note that ( a √2, b √ 2 ) = (a cos π 4 , b sin π 4 ) and this point is attained by the parametriza- tion ⃗r(t) at t = π 4 . Therefore, the unit tangent vector at ( a √2, b √2) is ˆT (π/4) = ⟨−a, b⟩ √a2 + b2 . (c) We use the formula for curvature involving the cross product ⃗r ′(t) × ⃗r ′′(t) : ⃗r ′(t) = ⟨−a sin t, b cos t, 0⟩ ⃗r ′′(t) = ⟨−a cos t, −b sin t, 0⟩ ⃗r ′(t) × ⃗r ′′(t) = ⟨0, 0, ab⟩. The curvature is given by κ(t) = |⃗r ′(t) × ⃗r ′′(t)| |⃗r ′(t)|3 = ab (a2 sin2 t + b2 cos2 t)3/2 . In particular, the curvature at t = π/4 is κ(π/4) = 2 3/2ab (a2 + b2)3/2 . Suppose that the curve C is the intersection of the cylinder x2 + y2 = 1 with the surface z = x2 − y2. (a) Find a parameterization of C. (b) Determine the curvature of C at the point P = (1/ √2, 1/ √2, 0). (c) Find the osculating plane to C at the point P . In general, the osculating plane to a curve ⃗r (t) at the point ⃗r (t0) is the plane which ﬁts the curve best at ⃗r (t0). It passes through ⃗r (t0) and has normal vector ̂B(t0). (d) Find the radius and the centre of the osculating circle to C at the point P . Solution. (a) Let (x, y, z) be a point on C. We know that x2 + y2 = 1, so as usual, we use the angle from the positive x-axis to the point (x, y) on the xy-plane as the parameter to get x = cos t and y = sin t for 0 ≤ t ≤ 2π. This choice also determines z = x2 − y2 = cos 2 t − sin2 t, which gives the parametrization ⃗r (t) = ⟨cos t, sin t, cos 2 t − sin 2 t⟩. (b) Note that ⃗r (t) = P when t = π/4. We compute ⃗r ′(t) = ⟨− sin t, cos t, −4 cos t sin t⟩ ⃗r ′′(t) = ⟨− cos t, − sin t, 4(sin 2 t − cos 2 t)⟩ In particular, ⃗r ′(π/4) = ⟨− 1 √2 , 1 √2, −2⟩ ⃗r ′′(π/4) = ⟨− 1 √2 , − 1 √ 2 , 0⟩ |⃗r ′(π/4)| = √5 ⃗r ′(π/4) × ⃗r ′′(π/4) = ⟨− √2, √ 2, 1⟩ |⃗r ′(π/4) × ⃗r ′′(π/4)| = √5 So the curvature κ( π 4 ) = |⃗r ′(π/4) × ⃗r ′′(π/4)| |⃗r ′(π/4)|3 = 1 5 . (c) The binormal to C at P is ̂B(π/4) = ⃗r ′(π/4) × ⃗r ′′(π/4) |⃗r ′(π/4) × ⃗r ′′(π/4)| = 1 √5⟨− √2, √ 2, 1⟩. Page 2 Math 317 Quiz 1 Practice Solutions So the osculating plane to C at P is (−√ 2, √ 2, 1) · (x − 1 √ 2 , y − 1 √ 2 , z − 0) = 0, or equivalently, z = √2(x − y). (d) The osculating circle has radius 1/κ( π 4 ) = 5. From the computations in part (b), we have ̂T(π/4) = ⃗r ′(π/4) |⃗r ′(π/4)| = 1 √5 √2⟨−1, 1, −2 √ 2⟩. Therefore, ̂N( π 4 ) = ̂B( π 4 )× ̂T( π 4 ) = 1 √5⟨− √2, √ 2, 1⟩× 1 √5 √2⟨−1, 1, −2 √ 2⟩ = 1 √2⟨−1, −1, 0⟩. and the centre is ⃗r ( π 4 ) + 1 κ( π 4 ) ̂N( π 4 ) = ⟨ 1 √2, 1 √2, 0⟩ + 5⟨− 1 √2, − 1 √2, 0⟩ = ⟨−2 √ 2, −2 √2, 0⟩. 3. Consider a particle whose position at time t is given by ⃗r (t) = ⟨cos t, sin t, e t⟩. (a) Compute the velocity and acceleration. (b) Find the curvature κ(t) of the trajectory at the point ⃗r (t). (c) Find the tangential and the normal component of the acceleration. Solution. (a) ⃗v(t) = ⃗r ′(t) = ⟨− sin t, cos t, e t⟩ ⃗a(t) = ⃗r ′′(t) = ⟨− cos t, − sin t, e t⟩. (b) We have |⃗r ′(t)| = (1 + e2t) 1/2 and ⃗r ′(t) × ⃗r ′′(t) = ⟨et(sin t + cos t), e t(sin t − cos t), 1⟩ |⃗r ′(t) × ⃗r ′′(t)| = √ e2t((sin t + cos t)2 + (sin t − cos t)2) + 1 = √2e2t + 1. Therefore, κ(t) = |⃗r ′(t) × ⃗r ′′(t)| |⃗r ′(t)|3 = (2e 2t + 1)1/2 (e2t + 1)3/2 . Page 3 Math 317 Quiz 1 Practice Solutions (c) Let ⃗a = ⃗r ′′ = aT ˆT + aN ˆN . Then aT = d|⃗r ′(t)| dt = e 2t(1 + e 2t) −1/2 aN = κ(t)|⃗r ′(t)| 2 = (2e 2t + 1)1/2 (e2t + 1)3/2 (1 + e2t) = (2e 2t + 1)1/2 (e2t + 1)1/2 . 4. Consider a particle whose position at time t > 0 is given by ⃗r (t) = ⟨t 2, 2t, log t⟩. Here we use log t for the inverse of the exponential function: log e t = t. (a) Compute the velocity and acceleration. (b) Find the curvature κ(t) of the trajectory at the point ⃗r (t). (c) Find the tangential and the normal component of the acceleration. Solution. (a) Compute: v(t) = (2t, 2, t −1) a(t) = (2, 0, −t−2) (b) The speed is: |v(t)| = (4t 2 + 4 + t −2) 1/2 = [(2t + t−1)2]1/2 = 2t + t −1 = t −1(1 + 2t 2).
